entry.title: From C To X86 : Part0x01 Variables

link.title: From C To X86 : Part0x01 Variables

entry.content:
Welcome back for another action packed installment of x86 assembly for C programmers!

We’ll be focusing on all things varibles in this article. We’ll take a look at the two major allocation scenarios consisting of memory on the stack and memory on the heap.



The C code

#include <stdio.h>

int heap(){
	int *heap_addr = (int *) malloc(2 * sizeof(int));
	printf("this is the heap address we got from malloc: 0x%d\n", heap_addr);
	*heap_addr = 5; //simple assignment.
	heap_addr[0] = 6; //array style notation to do the same as the last assignment
	return 0;
}

int stack(){
	int x = 1;
	int y = 2;
	x = 3;
	x = y;
	return 0;
}

int main(){
	heap();
	stack();
	return 0;
}

Laid out above are a set of functions that will allocate variables in different contexts.

With that, how about we bust up some assembly?



Assembly breakdown

main()

The scope of the variable below is inside the main() function. Since we assigned it a value directly without using dynamic memory given to us by our weapon of choice (calloc, malloc, etc…), this varibale will live on the stack.

int main_x = 8;

This is made evident by the following lines. (note these are not sequential in the actual binary, I ordered them for the example):

; var int local_10h @ ebp-0x10
0x08048544      83ec14         sub esp, 0x14
0x08048552      c745f0080000.  mov dword [local_10h], 8

Above is a pretty straightforward allocation and assignment procedure for a variable sotred on the stack.

We get a hint that it is on the stack from the first line, a comment from radare2 telling us it labled the space at ebp-0x10 as a local varibale of type int.

Next we substract from the ESP to make room for local variables, followed up by a simple mov instruction to litteraly move the value into the location pointed to by the local_10h address.

Here is a diagram to help, imagine if there was only one local var and replace the name with local_10h:

Note: Not all local stack variables will be used to represent things you explicitly created.

An important take away from this section is to recognize that a local stack variable is nothing more than an offset from the EBP (base pointer).

As the stack shrinks when it grows, you should recognize that the stack variables will be held in the address space between the ESP and the EBP.


stack()

In the case of our “stack” function, we’ll break it down into two parts.

Below are the simple allocations, assign a value into the location (memory address) pointed to by local_8h.

int x = 1;
int y = 2;
x = 3;

0x080484e0      83ec10         sub esp, 0x10
0x080484e3      c745f8010000.  mov dword [local_8h], 1
0x080484ea      c745fc020000.  mov dword [local_4h], 2 
0x080484f1      c745f8030000.  mov dword [local_8h], 3

We’re local_8h not wrapped in [], it would be like we are saying “replace the address held in local_8h with 1”.

Notice the substitution of the stack pointer to make way for our variables X and Y.

Also, you might be asking “why are there two extra bytes subtracted from the ESP?”. For now, consider that compiler magic.


Next up is an assignment operation with a little more beef to it:

x = y;
return 0;

First two lines below are responsible for moving the value held at local_4h into the EAX, followed by again, moving the value we put in EAX into the location local_8h points to.

The rest simply helps with returning zero.

0x080484f8      8b45fc         mov eax, dword [local_4h]
0x080484fb      8945f8         mov dword [local_8h], eax
0x080484fe      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x08048503      c9             leave
0x08048504      c3             ret



heap()

Now we’ll take a look at a different style of memory allocation entirely, with the help of our friend the heap.

First is the simple allocation of the starting address to the memory region we were given:

int *heap_addr = (int *) malloc(2 * sizeof(int));

This simple assignment translates to the following assembly operations:

0x080484a4      6a08           push 8                      ; 8                                           
0x080484a6      e8c5feffff     call sym.imp.malloc         ;[2] ;  void *malloc(size_t size)
0x080484ae      8945f4         mov dword [local_ch], eax

The 8 bytes being pushed onto the stack represent our request for 2 times the size of an int (32-bit so 4 bytes(int) times two).

Also remember that parameters are generally passed on the stack in a 32 bit environment

Next up is moving the value in EAX (the return value from malloc) into where lable local_ch points to. In our case, this is heap_addr(local_ch or ebp-0xc).

An important take away from this section is the [var] notation in assembly is similar to de-refferencing a pointer in C.


Now that we have stored our address in the pointer at local_ch, we can make use of this address for assignments:

*heap_addr = 5; //simple assignment.
heap_addr[0] = 6; //array style notation to do the same as the last assignment
return 0;

Translated to assembly, we can see that we move the contents of the variable local_ch into the EAX (heap address). Once in the EAX, we de-refference the address to place 5 in it.

Also note that regardless of C syntax, both assignment operations translate to the same assembly.

0x080484c4      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]
0x080484c7      c70005000000   mov dword [eax], 5
0x080484cd      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]
0x080484d0      c70006000000   mov dword [eax], 6
0x080484d6      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x080484db      c9             leave
0x080484dc      c3             ret



Are you sweating from all the adrenaline coarsing through your veins yet? I know that I sure am! Sadly, that about does it for this session.

Below is the full assembly dump of the binary we have been disecting, as is tradition. (I cut some extra instructions from the samples above for simplicity.):

 (fcn) sym.heap 66                                                                                                                                                   
|   sym.heap ();                                                                                                                                                      
|           ; var int local_ch @ ebp-0xc                                                                                                                              
|              ; CALL XREF from 0x080484c2 (sym.main)                                                                                                                 
|           0x0804843b      55             push ebp                                                                                                                   
|           0x0804843c      89e5           mov ebp, esp                                                                                                               
|           0x0804843e      83ec18         sub esp, 0x18                                                                                                              
|           0x08048441      83ec0c         sub esp, 0xc                                                                                                               
|           0x08048444      6a08           push 8                      ; 8                                                                                            
|           0x08048446      e8c5feffff     call sym.imp.malloc         ;[2] ;  void *malloc(size_t size)                                                              
|           0x0804844b      83c410         add esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x0804844e      8945f4         mov dword [local_ch], eax                                                                                                  
|           0x08048451      83ec08         sub esp, 8                                                                                                                 
|           0x08048454      ff75f4         push dword [local_ch]                                                                                                      
|           0x08048457      6870850408     push str.this_is_the_heap_address_we_got_from_malloc:_0x_d_n ; 0x8048570 ; "this is the heap address we got from malloc: 0x
|           0x0804845c      e89ffeffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[3] ; int printf(const char *format)                                                          
|           0x08048461      83c410         add esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x08048464      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]                                                                                                  
|           0x08048467      c70005000000   mov dword [eax], 5                                                                                                         
|           0x0804846d      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]                                                                                                  
|           0x08048470      c70006000000   mov dword [eax], 6                                                                                                         
|           0x08048476      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                                                 
|           0x0804847b      c9             leave                                                                                                                      
\           0x0804847c      c3             ret                                                                                                                       


/ (fcn) sym.stack 40                                                                                                                                                  
|   sym.stack ();                                                                                                                                                     
|           ; var int local_8h @ ebp-0x8                                                                                                                              
|           ; var int local_4h @ ebp-0x4                                                                                                                              
|              ; CALL XREF from 0x080484bd (sym.main)                                                                                                                 
|           0x0804847d      55             push ebp                                                                                                                   
|           0x0804847e      89e5           mov ebp, esp                                                                                                               
|           0x08048480      83ec10         sub esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x08048483      c745f8010000.  mov dword [local_8h], 1                                                                                                    
|           0x0804848a      c745fc020000.  mov dword [local_4h], 2                                                                                                    
|           0x08048491      c745f8030000.  mov dword [local_8h], 3                                                                                                    
|           0x08048498      8b45fc         mov eax, dword [local_4h]                                                                                                  
|           0x0804849b      8945f8         mov dword [local_8h], eax                                                                                                  
|           0x0804849e      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                                                 
|           0x080484a3      c9             leave                                                                                                                      
\           0x080484a4      c3             ret                                                                                                                        


/ (fcn) sym.main 66                                                                                                                                                   
|   sym.main ();                                                                                                                                                      
|           ; var int local_ch @ ebp-0xc                                                                                                                              
|           ; var int local_4h_2 @ ebp-0x4                                                                                                                            
|           ; var int local_4h @ esp+0x4                                                                                                                              
|              ; DATA XREF from 0x08048357 (entry0)                                                                                                                   
|           0x080484a5      8d4c2404       lea ecx, [local_4h]         ; 4                                                                                            
|           0x080484a9      83e4f0         and esp, 0xfffffff0                                                                                                        
|           0x080484ac      ff71fc         push dword [ecx - 4]                                                                                                       
|           0x080484af      55             push ebp                                                                                                                   
|           0x080484b0      89e5           mov ebp, esp                                                                                                               
|           0x080484b2      51             push ecx                                                                                                                   
|           0x080484b3      83ec14         sub esp, 0x14                                                                                                              
|           0x080484b6      c745f4080000.  mov dword [local_ch], 8                                                                                                    
|           0x080484bd      e8bbffffff     call sym.stack              ;[1]                                                                                           
|           0x080484c2      e874ffffff     call sym.heap               ;[2]                                                                                           
|           0x080484c7      83ec08         sub esp, 8                                                                                                                 
|           0x080484ca      ff75f4         push dword [local_ch]                                                                                                      
|           0x080484cd      68a3850408     push str.we_changed_main_x:__d_n ; 0x80485a3 ; "we changed main_x: %d\n"                                                   
|           0x080484d2      e829feffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[3] ; int printf(const char *format)                                                          
|           0x080484d7      83c410         add esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x080484da      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                                                 
|           0x080484df      8b4dfc         mov ecx, dword [local_4h_2]                                                                                                
|           0x080484e2      c9             leave                                                                                                                      
|           0x080484e3      8d61fc         lea esp, [ecx - 4]

category.term: assmebly asm for C programmers tutorial

entry.summary: Welcome back for another action packed installment of x86 assembly for C programmers!

entry.title: From C To X86 : Part0x01 Variables

link.title: From C To X86 : Part0x01 Variables

entry.content:
Welcome back for another action packed installment of x86 assembly for C programmers!

We’ll be focusing on all things varibles in this article. We’ll take a look at the two major allocation scenarios consisting of memory on the stack and memory on the heap.



The C code

#include <stdio.h>

int heap(){
	int *heap_addr = (int *) malloc(2 * sizeof(int));
	printf("this is the heap address we got from malloc: 0x%d\n", heap_addr);
	*heap_addr = 5; //simple assignment.
	heap_addr[0] = 6; //array style notation to do the same as the last assignment
	return 0;
}

int stack(){
	int x = 1;
	int y = 2;
	x = 3;
	x = y;
	return 0;
}

int main(){
	heap();
	stack();
	return 0;
}

Laid out above are a set of functions that will allocate variables in different contexts.

With that, how about we bust up some assembly?



Assembly breakdown

main()

The scope of the variable below is inside the main() function. Since we assigned it a value directly without using dynamic memory given to us our weapon of choice (calloc, malloc, etc…), this varibale will live on the stack.

int main_x = 8;

This is made evident by the following lines. (note these are not sequential in the actual binary, I ordered them for the example):

; var int local_10h @ ebp-0x10
0x08048544      83ec14         sub esp, 0x14
0x08048552      c745f0080000.  mov dword [local_10h], 8

Above is a pretty straightforward allocation and assignment procedure for a variable sotred on the stack.

We get a hint that it is on the stack from the first line, a comment from radare2 telling us it labled the space at ebp-0x10 as a local varibale of type int.

Next we substract from the ESP to make room for local variables, followed up by a simple mov instruction to litteraly move the value into the location pointed to by the local_10h address.

Here is a diagram to help, imagine if there was only one local var and replace the name with local_10h:

Note: Not all local stack variables will be used to represent things you explicitly created.

An important take away from this section is to recognize that a local stack variable is nothing more than an offset from the EBP (base pointer).

As the stack shrinks when it grows, you should recognize that the stack variables will be held in the address space between the ESP and the EBP.


stack()

In the case of our “stack” function, we’ll break it down into two parts.

Below are the simple allocations, assign a value into the location (memory address) pointed to by local_8h.

int x = 1;
int y = 2;
x = 3;

0x080484e0      83ec10         sub esp, 0x10
0x080484e3      c745f8010000.  mov dword [local_8h], 1
0x080484ea      c745fc020000.  mov dword [local_4h], 2 
0x080484f1      c745f8030000.  mov dword [local_8h], 3

We’re local_8h not wrapped in [], it would be like we are saying “replace the address held in local_8h with 1”.

Notice the substitution of the stack pointer to make way for our variables X and Y.

Also, you might be asking “why are there two extra bytes subtracted from the ESP?”. For now, consider that compiler magic.


Next up is an assignment operation with a little more beef to it:

x = y;
return 0;

First two lines below are responsible for moving the value held at local_4h into the EAX, followed by again, moving the value we put in EAX into the location local_8h points to.

The rest simply helps with returning zero.

0x080484f8      8b45fc         mov eax, dword [local_4h]
0x080484fb      8945f8         mov dword [local_8h], eax
0x080484fe      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x08048503      c9             leave
0x08048504      c3             ret



heap()

Now we’ll take a look at a different style of memory allocation entirely, with the help of our friend the heap.

First is the simple allocation of the starting address to the memory region we were given:

int *heap_addr = (int *) malloc(2 * sizeof(int));

This simple assignment translates to the following assembly operations:

0x080484a4      6a08           push 8                      ; 8                                           
0x080484a6      e8c5feffff     call sym.imp.malloc         ;[2] ;  void *malloc(size_t size)
0x080484ae      8945f4         mov dword [local_ch], eax

The 8 bytes being pushed onto the stack represent our request for 2 times the size of an int (32-bit so 4 bytes(int) times two).

Also remember that parameters are generally passed on the stack in a 32 bit environment

Next up is moving the value in EAX (the return value from malloc) into where lable local_ch points to. In our case, this is heap_addr(local_ch or ebp-0xc).

An important take away from this section is the [var] notation in assembly is similar to de-refferencing a pointer in C.


Now that we have stored our address in the pointer at local_ch, we can make use of this address for assignments:

*heap_addr = 5; //simple assignment.
heap_addr[0] = 6; //array style notation to do the same as the last assignment
return 0;

Translated to assembly, we can see that we move the contents of the variable local_ch into the EAX (heap address). Once in the EAX, we de-refference the address to place 5 in it.

Also note that regardless of C syntax, both assignment operations translate to the same assembly.

0x080484c4      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]
0x080484c7      c70005000000   mov dword [eax], 5
0x080484cd      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]
0x080484d0      c70006000000   mov dword [eax], 6
0x080484d6      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x080484db      c9             leave
0x080484dc      c3             ret



Are you sweating from all the adrenaline coarsing through your veins yet? I know that I sure am! Sadly, that about does it for this session.

Below is the full assembly dump of the binary we have been disecting, as is tradition. (I cut some extra instructions from the samples above for simplicity.):

 (fcn) sym.heap 66                                                                                                                                                   
|   sym.heap ();                                                                                                                                                      
|           ; var int local_ch @ ebp-0xc                                                                                                                              
|              ; CALL XREF from 0x080484c2 (sym.main)                                                                                                                 
|           0x0804843b      55             push ebp                                                                                                                   
|           0x0804843c      89e5           mov ebp, esp                                                                                                               
|           0x0804843e      83ec18         sub esp, 0x18                                                                                                              
|           0x08048441      83ec0c         sub esp, 0xc                                                                                                               
|           0x08048444      6a08           push 8                      ; 8                                                                                            
|           0x08048446      e8c5feffff     call sym.imp.malloc         ;[2] ;  void *malloc(size_t size)                                                              
|           0x0804844b      83c410         add esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x0804844e      8945f4         mov dword [local_ch], eax                                                                                                  
|           0x08048451      83ec08         sub esp, 8                                                                                                                 
|           0x08048454      ff75f4         push dword [local_ch]                                                                                                      
|           0x08048457      6870850408     push str.this_is_the_heap_address_we_got_from_malloc:_0x_d_n ; 0x8048570 ; "this is the heap address we got from malloc: 0x
|           0x0804845c      e89ffeffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[3] ; int printf(const char *format)                                                          
|           0x08048461      83c410         add esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x08048464      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]                                                                                                  
|           0x08048467      c70005000000   mov dword [eax], 5                                                                                                         
|           0x0804846d      8b45f4         mov eax, dword [local_ch]                                                                                                  
|           0x08048470      c70006000000   mov dword [eax], 6                                                                                                         
|           0x08048476      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                                                 
|           0x0804847b      c9             leave                                                                                                                      
\           0x0804847c      c3             ret                                                                                                                       


/ (fcn) sym.stack 40                                                                                                                                                  
|   sym.stack ();                                                                                                                                                     
|           ; var int local_8h @ ebp-0x8                                                                                                                              
|           ; var int local_4h @ ebp-0x4                                                                                                                              
|              ; CALL XREF from 0x080484bd (sym.main)                                                                                                                 
|           0x0804847d      55             push ebp                                                                                                                   
|           0x0804847e      89e5           mov ebp, esp                                                                                                               
|           0x08048480      83ec10         sub esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x08048483      c745f8010000.  mov dword [local_8h], 1                                                                                                    
|           0x0804848a      c745fc020000.  mov dword [local_4h], 2                                                                                                    
|           0x08048491      c745f8030000.  mov dword [local_8h], 3                                                                                                    
|           0x08048498      8b45fc         mov eax, dword [local_4h]                                                                                                  
|           0x0804849b      8945f8         mov dword [local_8h], eax                                                                                                  
|           0x0804849e      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                                                 
|           0x080484a3      c9             leave                                                                                                                      
\           0x080484a4      c3             ret                                                                                                                        


/ (fcn) sym.main 66                                                                                                                                                   
|   sym.main ();                                                                                                                                                      
|           ; var int local_ch @ ebp-0xc                                                                                                                              
|           ; var int local_4h_2 @ ebp-0x4                                                                                                                            
|           ; var int local_4h @ esp+0x4                                                                                                                              
|              ; DATA XREF from 0x08048357 (entry0)                                                                                                                   
|           0x080484a5      8d4c2404       lea ecx, [local_4h]         ; 4                                                                                            
|           0x080484a9      83e4f0         and esp, 0xfffffff0                                                                                                        
|           0x080484ac      ff71fc         push dword [ecx - 4]                                                                                                       
|           0x080484af      55             push ebp                                                                                                                   
|           0x080484b0      89e5           mov ebp, esp                                                                                                               
|           0x080484b2      51             push ecx                                                                                                                   
|           0x080484b3      83ec14         sub esp, 0x14                                                                                                              
|           0x080484b6      c745f4080000.  mov dword [local_ch], 8                                                                                                    
|           0x080484bd      e8bbffffff     call sym.stack              ;[1]                                                                                           
|           0x080484c2      e874ffffff     call sym.heap               ;[2]                                                                                           
|           0x080484c7      83ec08         sub esp, 8                                                                                                                 
|           0x080484ca      ff75f4         push dword [local_ch]                                                                                                      
|           0x080484cd      68a3850408     push str.we_changed_main_x:__d_n ; 0x80485a3 ; "we changed main_x: %d\n"                                                   
|           0x080484d2      e829feffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[3] ; int printf(const char *format)                                                          
|           0x080484d7      83c410         add esp, 0x10                                                                                                              
|           0x080484da      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                                                 
|           0x080484df      8b4dfc         mov ecx, dword [local_4h_2]                                                                                                
|           0x080484e2      c9             leave                                                                                                                      
|           0x080484e3      8d61fc         lea esp, [ecx - 4]

category.term: assmebly asm for C programmers tutorial

entry.summary: Welcome back for another action packed installment of x86 assembly for C programmers!

entry.title: From C To X86 : Part0x00 Pointers

link.title: From C To X86 : Part0x00 Pointers

entry.content:
This is the first installment of the x86 series where we cover the basics of assembly from a C programmers perspective.

Today we will focus on the basics of pointers with the help of a simple C example.



The C code

#include <stdio.h>


int main(){
	char our_char = 'Q';
	char *ptr_x = &our_char;

	printf("this is your ptr_x addr: 0x%x\n", &ptr_x);
	printf("the value stored in ptr_x: 0x%x\n", ptr_x);
	printf("here is the value it points to: %s\n", *ptr_x);
	return 0;
}

We can see that it allocates a char, passes its address to a pointer, followed by printing the three different pieces that make up the pointer in question.

Pretty straightforward stuff so far right? Now let’s dive head first into some assembly!



Assembly breakdown

Here we see the allocation and assignment of the address for variable our_char to ptr_x:

char our_char = 'Q';
char *ptr_x = &our_char;

0x004005ad      c645ef51       mov byte [local_11h], 0x51  ; 'Q'
0x004005b1      488d45ef       lea rax, [local_11h]
0x004005b5      488945f0       mov qword [local_10h], rax

At this point, the value “Q” is stored on the stack at local_11h.

The address for the value was loaded into the rax, followed by assigning it to our ptr_x which is also on the stack at local_10h.



Next up is the first print statement. In order to print the address of the pointer variable, the effective address of its position on the stack (local_10h) must be passed to printf:

printf("this is your ptr_x addr: 0x%x\n", &ptr_x);

0x004005b9      488d45f0       lea rax, [local_10h]   
0x004005bd      4889c6         mov rsi, rax 
0x004005c0      bfa8064000     mov edi, str.this_is_your_ptr_x_addr:_0x_x_n ;
0x004005c5      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x004005ca      e8a1feffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[1] ; int printf(const char *format)



Printing the address of the pointer variable is followed by printing the address it is responsible for storing. In order to acheive this, we simmply derefference the local_10h variable, store it in rax and pass the value to printf:

printf("the value stored in ptr_x: 0x%x\n", ptr_x);

0x004005cf      488b45f0       mov rax, qword [local_10h]
0x004005d3      4889c6         mov rsi, rax
0x004005d6      bfc8064000     mov edi, str.this_is_your_ptr_x_value:_0x_x_n ;        
0x004005db      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x004005e0      e88bfeffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[1] ; int printf(const char *format)



Finally, the trickiest part, printing the value the pointer is pointing to.

Accomplishing this requires us to perform a double derefference. First, by derefferencing local_10h (our_char address) into a register, followed by derefferencing said address to get the value “Q” stored into the eax.

printf("here is the value it points to: %s\n", *ptr_x);

0x004005e5      488b45f0       mov rax, qword [local_10h]
0x004005e9      0fb600         movzx eax, byte [rax]
0x004005ec      0fbec0         movsx eax, al
0x004005ef      89c6           mov esi, eax
0x004005f1      bfe8064000     mov edi, str.finally__here_is_the_value_it_points_to:__c_n ;
0x004005f6      b800000000     mov eax, 0
0x004005fb      e870feffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[1] ; int printf(const char *format)



And there you have it! We’ve printed everything out and our parents are proud. Below you can find the full assembly dump. Until next time!

/ (fcn) sym.main 133                                                                                                                  
|   sym.main ();                                                                                                                      
|           ; var int local_11h @ rbp-0x11                                                                                            
|           ; var int local_10h @ rbp-0x10                                                                                            
|           ; var int local_8h @ rbp-0x8                                                                                              
|              ; DATA XREF from 0x004004bd (entry0)                                                                                   
|           0x00400596      55             push rbp                                                                                   
|           0x00400597      4889e5         mov rbp, rsp                                                                               
|           0x0040059a      4883ec20       sub rsp, 0x20                                                                              
|           0x0040059e      64488b042528.  mov rax, qword fs:[0x28]    ; [0x28:8]=-1 ; '(' ; 40                                       
|           0x004005a7      488945f8       mov qword [local_8h], rax                                                                  
|           0x004005ab      31c0           xor eax, eax                                                                               
|           0x004005ad      c645ef51       mov byte [local_11h], 0x51  ; 'Q'                                                          
|           0x004005b1      488d45ef       lea rax, [local_11h]                                                                       
|           0x004005b5      488945f0       mov qword [local_10h], rax                                                                 
|           0x004005b9      488d45f0       lea rax, [local_10h]                                                                       
|           0x004005bd      4889c6         mov rsi, rax
|           0x004005c0      bfa8064000     mov edi, str.this_is_your_ptr_x_addr:_0x_x_n ; 0x4006a8 ; "this is your ptr_x addr: 0x%x\n"
|           0x004005c5      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                 
|           0x004005ca      e8a1feffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[1] ; int printf(const char *format)                          
|           0x004005cf      488b45f0       mov rax, qword [local_10h]                                                                 
|           0x004005d3      4889c6         mov rsi, rax                                                                               
|           0x004005d6      bfc8064000     mov edi, str.this_is_your_ptr_x_value:_0x_x_n ; 0x4006c8 ; "this is your ptr_x value: 0x%x\
|           0x004005db      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                 
|           0x004005e0      e88bfeffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[1] ; int printf(const char *format)                          
|           0x004005e5      488b45f0       mov rax, qword [local_10h]                                                                 
|           0x004005e9      0fb600         movzx eax, byte [rax]                                                                      
|           0x004005ec      0fbec0         movsx eax, al                                                                              
|           0x004005ef      89c6           mov esi, eax                                                                               
|           0x004005f1      bfe8064000     mov edi, str.finally__here_is_the_value_it_points_to:__c_n ; 0x4006e8 ; "finally, here is t
|           0x004005f6      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                 
|           0x004005fb      e870feffff     call sym.imp.printf         ;[1] ; int printf(const char *format)                          
|           0x00400600      b800000000     mov eax, 0                                                                                 
|           0x00400605      488b55f8       mov rdx, qword [local_8h]                                                                  
|           0x00400609      644833142528.  xor rdx, qword fs:[0x28]                                                                   
|       ,=< 0x00400612      7405           je 0x400619                 ;[2]                                                           
|           0x00400614      e847feffff     call sym.imp.__stack_chk_fail ;[3] ; sym.imp.printf-0x10 ; int printf(const char *format)  
|       `-> 0x00400619      c9             leave                                                                              
\           0x0040061a      c3             ret

category.term: assmebly asm for C programmers tutorial

entry.summary: This is the first installment of the x86 series where we cover the basics of assembly from a C programmers perspective.

entry.title: Super_beam
entry.content:
Summary

edit: This vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2017-17763.

SuperBeam is an excellent file transfer application which enables users from iOS, Android and even a PC to seamlessly transfer files through WiFi direct, over a local LAN or via NFC.

With over 10 PB of file transfers since its creation and well over 10 million downloads, it is certainly a mainstay in the file transfer market.

Playing around with it recently, we were able to spot a few flaws within the file transfer process. Given a properly placed attacker, the possibility to arbitrarily inject data into any given transfer is alive and well!



Affected Products

Versions of SuperBeam / WiFi Direct Share <= 4.1.3



Impact

During the file transfer process, SuperBeam will offer up the file to be transferred via an HTTP server hosted on the sending device. Any properly positioned attacker is able to arbitrarily inject anything from a text file to an APK onto the receivers’ device through a MiTM attack.

This is accomplished by having the attacker spoof the sending device via ARP Poisoning, while simultaneously running an instance of SuperBeam, whether as an app or the PC version.

The most significant impact appears to be in the context of users making use of SuperBeam to transfer apps. In this type of transfer, a user is inclined to install and run whatever they receive, making this a perfect scenario for the attacker to inject a malicious APK.



Technical Details / Proof of Concept

Over the LAN

The majority of the research was performed using devices on the same LAN, although via WiFi direct, the results are no different, i.e., sender starts an HTTP server on a LAN and waits for GET requests, no data validation.

Below we will walk through an APK injection scenario / POC. This could just as easily have been a scenario where two parties are exchanging public keys and the attackers injects their own.

Here we see a user initiate a file transfer by selecting an app to send via SuperBeam:

SuperBeam is now active and has set up a server that will provide the flashlight app APK:

Here we see that the attacker has poisoned the receivers ARP cache, pretending to be the sender at 192.168.2.27:

The attacker can then run an instance of SuperBeam on a mobile device or a PC and offer up the content they intend to inject into the transfer:

NOTE: Only the pro version enables downloads to mobile from PC, inadvertently increasing the attack surface for paying customers only. Otherwise, the receiver is met with the following:

Next, the receiver will simply scan the QR code provided by the sender, this will issue the following requests:

Since we are injecting our malicious APK via the PC version of SuperBeam, we don’t offer up a jsonlist, hence the 404.

Below are the contents of the jsonlist offered up by the sending device:

Had this scenario been weaponized, the attacker could have used the information provided by the jsonlist from the original sender to mirror the application being transferred, leaving the receiver suspecting nothing.

On the attacker side at this point, we see the request come into our SuperBeam instance instead of the true sender’s instance:

The receiver will be none the wiser as there are zero data integrity checks performed on the content received:

Finally, the user simply steps through the installation process and the device is now fully compromised:



Over WiFi Direct

Due to the nature of the implementation of the WiFi Direct file transfer feature in SuperBeam, the attack described above will have no trouble functioning in a WiFi Direct scenario.

Although some extra effort will be required on the part of the attacker in order to gain access to the LAN created by SuperBeam.

SuperBeam performs a WiFi Direct transfer with the help of a temporary wireless access point, hosted by the device sending files:

After experimenting with how the application sets up this temporary network, a few flaws were uncovered that make it possible for an attacker to break into the network.

  • Static SSID: As seen in the figure above, the SSID for SuperBeam WiFi direct transfers all follow a similar structure. (Ex: “DIRECT-Yf-S”, DIRECT--S). Once set, it looks to persist even after deleting the app and reinstalling it.

  • Static WPA2 Key: The temporary network makes use of an 8 character password composed of lower and upper case letters, as well as numbers (no special characters observed during the period of this audit).

An attacker could capture a handshake between client and server, collect a hash of the key and perform an offline hash cracking attack on the 8 character password.

Since it is the case that the password appears to be static for all transfers initiated by a given sender, once cracked, the attacker has the ability to MiTM every instance of a WiFi Direct transfer offered by the sender in question.



Recommended Mitigation

The vulnerabilities in the current version of SuperBeam boil down to the lack of any form of data validation.

In order to patch up SuperBeam, the following modifications are recommended:



HTTPS

Offer up all file transfers via HTTPS in order to help make arbitrary MiTM attacks on the file transfer process less trivial.



Data validation

Using a shared secret between the sender and receiver, the files transferred could have HMACs calculated on them.

Even if the attacker could inject their own file into the transfer, without knowledge of the shared secret, the attacker should not be able to calculate a valid HMAC for their injected file.

At the very least, this would provide SuperBeam a way to validate that the data being transferred was not tampered with.



Beef up WiFi Direct

It would be highly advisable to simply randomize the SSID used by the wifi direct transfer every time a new SuperBeam server starts up.

Not only the SSID but the network key should also change every transfer. If it were randomized, even with a weak 8 character key, the cracked key would only be useful to the attacker for a single wifi direct transfer.

This would render efforts to crack it offline for future use completely futile, as the window of opportunity is reduced to a single transfer.

Once set, it looks to persist even after deleting the app and reinstalling it. An attacker could capture a handshake between client and server, collect a hash of the key and perform an offline hash cracking attack on the 8 character password.Since it is the case that the password appears to be static for all transfers initiated by a given sender, once cracked, the attacker has the ability to MiTM every instance of a WiFi Direct transfer offered by the sender in question.Recommended MitigationThe vulnerabilities in the current version of SuperBeam boil down to the lack of any form of data validation.In order to patch up SuperBeam, the following modifications are recommended:HTTPSOffer up all file transfers via HTTPS in order to help make arbitrary MiTM attacks on the file transfer process less trivial.Data validationUsing a shared secret between the sender and receiver, the files transferred could have HMACs calculated on them.Even if the attacker could inject their own file into the transfer, without knowledge of the shared secret, the attacker should not be able to calculate a valid HMAC for their injected file.At the very least, this would provide SuperBeam a way to validate that the data being transferred was not tampered with.Beef up WiFi DirectIt would be highly advisable to simply randomize the SSID used by the wifi direct transfer every time a new SuperBeam server starts up.Not only the SSID but the network key should also change every transfer.
